text:
AWS CloudShell makes it easy to securely 
manage, explore, and interact with AWS

resources directly from a browser. In this demo, 
weâ€™ll learn how to launch a new CloudShell

environment and use the available features to 
help us focus more on building our AWS

resources and less on maintaining our local machines. 
To get started, we simply click the AWS CloudShell

icon in the top navigation bar from any supported region. 
In just a few seconds, we have access to a Linux

terminal with a wide range of pre-installed tools, such 
as the AWS CLI and the AWS Elastic Beanstalk,

Amazon Elastic Container Service, and 
AWS SAM CLIs.

The shell environment is pre-configured with our 
AWS credentials, allowing us to seamlessly

interact with our AWS account the same way we would 
using the AWS Console.
Let's use the AWS ECS CLI to create an ECS cluster.

We also have the programming language runtimes and 
AWS SDKs for Python and Node.js built-in, as well as the

ability to install additional software as needed. Here, we've 
just installed the AWS Cloud Development Kit globally, and

used it to initialize a new application. Any global changes we 
make to the operating system will last until our CloudShell

session expires (even if we exit and return to CloudShell 
before it times out), but we have 1 GB of persistent

storage available in our home directory that will still be 
there when we launch a new session.

And of course, we can download our files from 
CloudShell to use locally,

or we can use the AWS CLI to back them up to
Amazon S3.

We can also use this space to store additional user scripts and
configuration preferences to automatically customize our

environment the way we like it. For example, if we prefer Z shell
over Bash, we could modify the file ".bash_profile" in our

home directory to switch to Z shell when we open a new session. 
We could then install one of the popular Z shell configuration

frameworks and customize it to our liking using various plugins 
or themes - just as if we were working in a local shell!

Visit aws.amazon.com/cloudshell/ to learn more about how
you can make it part of your toolset today!
